questions:
A 28-year-old-man attends the emergency department having taken a deliberate overdose of paracetamol. He states that he took 26 tablets, each containing 500 milligrams of paracetamol. He took the tablets all at once, with intention to end his life. He now regrets taking the tablets and wishes to have full medical treatment.

You decide that you will need to take a paracetamol level to guide further treatment. What is the minimum time after ingestion of the tablets that a paracetamol level can be used to guide treatment with acetylcysteine?
notes:
A plasma paracetamol level taken less than four hours since ingestion can underestimate the total ingestion of paracetamol, as the drug is still being absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract at this point. Therefore, it is important to wait until this point to take a blood sample, which can then be plotted on the treatment nomogram.

Patients who present within one hour of ingestion may benefit from activated charcoal to reduce absorption of the drug. However, a paracetamol level at this stage is of limited value.

Patients who have an unknown ingestion time or who present having taken a staggered overdose might be started on acetylcysteine regardless of their paracetamol level. A staggered overdose refers to an overdose where the tablets are taken over a period of greater than an hour.
question:
A 28-year-old-man attends the emergency department having taken a deliberate overdose of paracetamol. He states that he took 26 tablets, each containing 500 milligrams of paracetamol. He took the tablets all at once, with intention to end his life. He now regrets taking the tablets and wishes to have full medical treatment.

You decide that you will need to take a paracetamol level to guide further treatment. What is the minimum time after ingestion of the tablets that a paracetamol level can be used to guide treatment with acetylcysteine?
question_notes:
A plasma paracetamol level taken less than four hours since ingestion can underestimate the total ingestion of paracetamol, as the drug is still being absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract at this point. Therefore, it is important to wait until this point to take a blood sample, which can then be plotted on the treatment nomogram.

Patients who present within one hour of ingestion may benefit from activated charcoal to reduce absorption of the drug. However, a paracetamol level at this stage is of limited value.

Patients who have an unknown ingestion time or who present having taken a staggered overdose might be started on acetylcysteine regardless of their paracetamol level. A staggered overdose refers to an overdose where the tablets are taken over a period of greater than an hour.
title: Paracetamol overdose: management
body:
The following is based on 2012 Commission on Human Medicines (CHM) review of paracetamol overdose management. The big change in these guidelines was the removal of the 'high-risk' treatment line on the normogram. All patients are therefore treated the same regardless of risk factors for hepatotoxicity. The National Poisons Information Service/TOXBASE should always be consulted for situations outside of the normal parameters.

The minority of patients who present within 1 hour may benefit from activated charcoal to reduce absorption of the drug.

Acetylcysteine should be given if:
  • the plasma paracetamol concentration is on or above a single treatment line joining points of 100 mg/L at 4 hours and 15 mg/L at 15 hours, regardless of risk factors of hepatotoxicity
  • there is a staggered overdose* or there is doubt over the time of paracetamol ingestion, regardless of the plasma paracetamol concentration; or
  • patients who present 8-24 hours after ingestion of an acute overdose of more than 150 mg/kg of paracetamol even if the plasma-paracetamol concentration is not yet available
  • patients who present > 24 hours if they are clearly jaundiced or have hepatic tenderness, their ALT is above the upper limit of normal
    • acetylcysteine should be continued if the paracetamol concentration or ALT remains elevated whilst seeking specialist advice

Acetylcysteine is now infused over 1 hour (rather than the previous 15 minutes) to reduce the number of adverse effects. Acetylcysteine commonly causes an anaphylactoid reaction (non-IgE mediated mast cell release). Anaphylactoid reactions to IV acetylcysteine are generally treated by stopping the infusion, then restarting at a slower rate.


King's College Hospital criteria for liver transplantation (paracetamol liver failure)

Arterial pH < 7.3, 24 hours after ingestion

or all of the following:
  • prothrombin time > 100 seconds
  • creatinine > 300 µmol/l
  • grade III or IV encephalopathy

*an overdose is considered staggered if all the tablets were not taken within 1 hour
concept: Plasma paracetamol levels obtained less than 4 hours since ingestion cannot be interpreted
links:
Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency1917
2012 Paracetamol overdose update

3125.concept_text: Patients who take a staggered paracetamol overdose should receive treatment with acetylcysteine

11440.concept_text: Liver transplantation criteria in paracetamol overdose: pH < 7.3 more than 24 hours after ingestion

11854.concept_text: Paracetamol overdose: if presentation 8-24 hours after ingestion of an overdose of more than 150 mg/kg start acetylcysteine even if the plasma-paracetamol concentration is not yet available

questions: You have ordered a B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) test on a patient with suspected heart failure. It has come back as being slightly elevated. Which one of the following factors may account for a falsely elevated BNP?
notes:
The correct answer is COPD. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) can cause falsely elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels. BNP is primarily released from ventricular myocytes in response to increased wall tension and volume overload. In COPD, particularly during exacerbations, patients can develop pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular strain, which can lead to increased BNP production. Additionally, the hypoxia and inflammatory state associated with COPD can directly stimulate BNP release. This means that when interpreting BNP results in patients with COPD, clinicians should consider that values may be elevated due to the underlying respiratory condition rather than heart failure alone.

ACE inhibitor therapy is incorrect. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors actually tend to reduce BNP levels rather than increase them. ACE inhibitors decrease cardiac preload and afterload, reducing ventricular wall stress and thereby decreasing the stimulus for BNP release. In patients with heart failure, ACE inhibitors are a cornerstone of therapy precisely because they reduce ventricular strain and improve cardiac remodelling. Therefore, ACE inhibitor therapy would not account for a falsely elevated BNP.

Beta-blocker therapy is incorrect. Similar to ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers typically reduce BNP levels in patients with heart failure over time. By blocking sympathetic stimulation of the heart, beta-blockers reduce heart rate, blood pressure, and myocardial oxygen demand, which leads to decreased ventricular wall stress. This results in reduced BNP production rather than elevation. Beta-blockers are an essential component of heart failure management and would not cause falsely elevated BNP readings.

Furosemide therapy is incorrect. Furosemide is a loop diuretic that reduces preload by increasing urinary sodium and water excretion. This reduction in preload decreases ventricular filling pressures and wall stress, which should lead to a reduction in BNP levels rather than an elevation. In heart failure management, diuretics like furosemide are used to relieve congestion, and successful diuresis is often associated with falling BNP levels as the heart's workload decreases.

Obesity is incorrect, but in an interesting way. Obesity is actually associated with lower BNP levels, not elevated ones. Adipose tissue contains natriuretic peptide clearance receptors that increase the clearance of BNP from circulation. This means that obese patients may have falsely low BNP levels relative to their degree of heart failure, not falsely elevated ones. Clinicians should consider using lower diagnostic thresholds for BNP when evaluating obese patients for heart failure.

title: Chronic heart failure: diagnosis
body:
NICE issued updated guidelines on diagnosis and management in 2018. Previously the first-line investigation was determined by whether the patient has previously had a myocardial infarction or not this is no longer the case - all patients should have an N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) blood test first-line.

Interpreting the test
  • if levels are 'high' arrange specialist assessment (including transthoracic echocardiography) within 2 weeks
  • if levels are 'raised' arrange specialist assessment (including transthoracic echocardiography) echocardiogram within 6 weeks

Serum natriuretic peptides

B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) is a hormone produced mainly by the left ventricular myocardium in response to strain. Very high levels are associated with a poor prognosis.

BNP NTproBNP
High levels> 400 pg/ml (116 pmol/litre)> 2000 pg/ml (236 pmol/litre)
Raised levels100-400 pg/ml (29-116 pmol/litre)400-2000 pg/ml (47-236 pmol/litre)
Normal levels< 100 pg/ml (29 pmol/litre)< 400 pg/ml (47 pmol/litre)

Factors which alter the BNP level:

Increase BNP levelsDecrease BNP levels
Left ventricular hypertrophy
Ischaemia
Tachycardia
Right ventricular overload
Hypoxaemia (including pulmonary embolism)
GFR < 60 ml/min
Sepsis
COPD
Diabetes
Age > 70
Liver cirrhosis		Obesity
Diuretics
ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers
Angiotensin 2 receptor blockers
Aldosterone antagonists

2018 Chronic heart failure guidelines

8594.concept_text: All patients with suspected chronic heart failure should have an NT-proBNP test first-line

questions:
A 12-year-old female presents to her GP with bilateral knee pain, swelling and stiffness. On examination, a salmon-pink rash is noted on the legs.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes: Joint pain with a salmon-pink rash is characteristic of juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Henoch-Schonlein purpura can cause joint pain, but the rash is palpable and purpuric. Meningitis causes a non-blanching purpuric rash with no joint pain. Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause joint pain and rash but is unusual in children and the rash is usually on the face. Measles can cause a pink rash but not joint pain.
question:
A 12-year-old female presents to her GP with bilateral knee pain, swelling and stiffness. On examination, a salmon-pink rash is noted on the legs.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
question_notes: Joint pain with a salmon-pink rash is characteristic of juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Henoch-Schonlein purpura can cause joint pain, but the rash is palpable and purpuric. Meningitis causes a non-blanching purpuric rash with no joint pain. Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause joint pain and rash but is unusual in children and the rash is usually on the face. Measles can cause a pink rash but not joint pain.
title: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis: systemic onset
body:
Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), now preferred to the older term juvenile chronic arthritis, describes arthritis occurring in someone who is less than 16 years old that lasts for more than 6 weeks. Systemic onset JIA is a type of JIA which is also known as Still's disease

Features of systemic onset JIA include
  • pyrexia
  • salmon-pink rash
  • lymphadenopathy
  • arthritis
  • uveitis
  • anorexia and weight loss

Investigations
  • ANA may be positive, especially in oligoarticular JIA
  • rheumatoid factor is usually negative
concept: Systemic onset JIA (AKA Still's disease) has a characteristic salmon-pink rash

theme: Sexual health presentation requiring treatment selection for trichomoniasis
questions:
A 28-year-old woman attends the sexual health clinic with a 10-day history of vaginal discharge and vulval irritation. She is sexually active with one partner. Examination reveals an offensive yellow-green discharge. Vaginal pH is 5.2. Microscopy of a wet mount shows motile flagellated organisms.

Select the single most appropriate treatment from the options below.
notes:
Oral metronidazole is the correct answer. This patient has classic features of Trichomonas vaginalis infection: offensive yellow-green discharge, elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), and the diagnostic finding of motile flagellated trophozoites on wet mount microscopy. Trichomonas vaginalis is a sexually transmitted protozoan infection that responds to nitroimidazole antibiotics. The standard treatment is oral metronidazole for 5-7 days, though a single 2g dose is also effective according to UK guidelines. It is important to treat sexual partners simultaneously to prevent reinfection, and patients should be advised to avoid alcohol during treatment and for 48 hours afterwards due to the disulfiram-like reaction. Other STIs should be screened for given the sexual transmission route.

Intravaginal clindamycin is used to treat bacterial vaginosis, which can present with vaginal discharge and elevated pH. However, bacterial vaginosis typically causes a thin, grey-white discharge with a fishy odour rather than the yellow-green frothy discharge seen here. The key distinguishing feature is the microscopy finding of motile trophozoites rather than clue cells, making this diagnosis incorrect for this patient.

Oral fluconazole is the treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis. Whilst candidiasis can cause vulval irritation and discharge, the discharge is typically thick, white, and cottage cheese-like rather than yellow-green and offensive. Additionally, candidiasis is associated with a normal vaginal pH (<4.5), and microscopy would show pseudohyphae and spores rather than motile organisms.

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is used to treat gonorrhoea, which can cause purulent vaginal discharge and cervicitis. However, gonorrhoea typically presents with a purulent rather than frothy discharge, and microscopy would show intracellular Gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain rather than motile flagellated organisms. The elevated pH and specific microscopy findings make trichomoniasis the clear diagnosis.

Oral doxycycline is used to treat chlamydia infection, which commonly presents with mucopurulent cervical discharge. However, chlamydia often causes minimal symptoms and would not produce the characteristic motile organisms seen on microscopy. The vaginal pH may be normal, and the specific microscopy findings of flagellated protozoa are diagnostic of trichomoniasis rather than chlamydia.

title: Trichomonas vaginalis
body:
Trichomonas vaginalis is a highly motile, flagellated protozoan parasite. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI).

Features
  • vaginal discharge: offensive, yellow/green, frothy
  • vulvovaginitis
  • strawberry cervix
  • pH > 4.5
  • in men is usually asymptomatic but may cause urethritis

Investigation
  • microscopy of a wet mount may show motile trophozoites
    • low sensitivity of around 50% but high specificity
  • nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are now regarded as the diagnostic gold standard for Trichomonas
    • sensitivity: >95–99%, specificity: >98–100%

Management
  • oral metronidazole for 5-7 days, although the BNF also supports the use of a one-off dose of 2g metronidazole

Comparison of bacterial vaginosis and Trichomonas vaginalis
media:
Trichomonas vaginalis
Khan Academy - YouTube43

308.concept_text: Trichomonas vaginalis + bacterial vaginosis are associated with a pH > 4.5

3311.concept_text: Trichomonas vaginalis: offensive yellow/green vaginal discharge, pH > 4.5

theme: Best valproate alternative for generalised tonic–clonic epilepsy
questions: A 34-year-old man is reviewed in the neurology clinic. He has been established on sodium valproate for primary generalised epilepsy. Despite now taking a therapeutic dose he continues to have seizures and is troubled by weight gain since starting sodium valproate. He asks to stop his current medication and try a different drug. Which one of the following drugs would be the most appropriate second-line treatment?
notes:
Lamotrigine is the most appropriate agent to switch to in a man with primary generalised (tonic–clonic) epilepsy who has failed or not tolerated sodium valproate. NICE CG137 recommends lamotrigine or levetiracetam as first-line options for generalised seizures when valproate is unsuitable. Lamotrigine has robust efficacy data in this seizure type, is generally weight-neutral and has a favourable cognitive profile, making it attractive to a patient already concerned about weight gain. Although it carries a risk of rash—including Stevens-Johnson syndrome—this is minimised by a slow titration schedule. Importantly, there are no UKMHRA warnings restricting its use in men of child-bearing potential age, unlike valproate or topiramate, and there are no major pharmacokinetic interactions with most concomitant drugs.

Topiramate is effective in generalised tonic–clonic seizures and can aid weight loss, so it may appear tempting. However, its significant neurocognitive adverse effects (word-finding difficulty, impaired concentration) and risk of renal stones make it less favourable than lamotrigine. Furthermore, new MHRA advice places topiramate under a Pregnancy Prevention Programme because of teratogenicity, which means women require complex counselling; although this patient is male, prescribers are encouraged to reserve topiramate for cases where safer agents have failed.

Carbamazepine is a mainstay for focal seizures but is relatively less effective for primary generalised epilepsy and may precipitate absence or myoclonic seizures. Its enzyme-inducing properties also complicate contraceptive and anticoagulant therapy. Hence, it is not recommended by NICE for generalised tonic-clonic seizures unless other agents are unsuitable.

Ethosuximide is the treatment of choice for absence (petit-mal) epilepsy, not for tonic–clonic seizures. It has little efficacy against generalised tonic–clonic events and may therefore leave the patient inadequately protected.

Phenytoin historically featured in the management of primary generalised epilepsy and does control tonic–clonic seizures. Nevertheless, it is now considered third-line because of complex, non-linear pharmacokinetics, cosmetic side-effects (gingival hypertrophy, hirsutism), osteoporosis risk and numerous drug interactions. Modern guidelines place lamotrigine well ahead of phenytoin for efficacy, tolerability and ease of use, making phenytoin an inferior choice in this scenario.

Despite now taking a therapeutic dose he continues to have seizures and is troubled by weight gain since starting sodium valproate. He asks to stop his current medication and try a different drug. Which one of the following drugs would be the most appropriate second-line treatment?

title: Epilepsy: treatment
body:
Most neurologists now start antiepileptics following a second epileptic seizure. NICE guidelines suggest starting antiepileptics after the first seizure if any of the following are present:
  • the patient has a neurological deficit
  • brain imaging shows a structural abnormality
  • the EEG shows unequivocal epileptic activity
  • the patient or their family or carers consider the risk of having a further seizure unacceptable


Safety considerations of specific drugs

The MHRA and NICE have strengthed their advice against sodium valproate use recently:


Valproate must not be started for the first time in people (male or female) younger than 55 years, unless 2 specialists independently consider and document that there is no other effective or tolerated treatment, or there are compelling reasons that the reproductive risks do not apply.

Topiramate should not be used in women and girls of childbearing potential unless conditions of the Pregnancy Prevention Programme are fulfilled.


Drug treatment according to the type of epilepsy

Generalised tonic-clonic seizures
  • lamotrigine or levetiracetam

Focal seizures
  • first line: lamotrigine or levetiracetam
  • second line: carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine or zonisamide

Absence seizures (Petit mal)
  • first line: ethosuximide
  • second line: lamotrigine or levetiracetam
  • carbamazepine may exacerbate absence seizures

Myoclonic seizures
  • first-line: levetiracetam
  • second line: lamotrigine

Tonic or atonic seizures
  • first-line: lamotrigine
  • second line: clobazam, rufinamide, or topiramate
links:

2013 Modern management of epilepsy


NICE3835
2022 Epilepsy guidelines

11841.concept_text: Tonic or atonic seizures: lamotrigine is first-line

questions: You perform a routine newborn examination on a baby with newly diagnosed Down syndrome. The mother notes 'white speckles on his eyes'. Eye examination is unremarkable with a bilateral red reflex. What is she describing?
notes:
Brushfield spots are small grey or brown spots seen on the periphery of the iris. They are associated with Down syndrome.

Cataracts are a clouding of the lens. Although associated with Down syndrome this patient has a normal red reflex therefore a congenital cataract is unlikely.

Coloboma is a congenital defect causing a gap in the lens, iris or retina. It is associated with Patau syndrome, not Down syndrome.

Congenital glaucoma is elevated pressure within the eye. Again there have been links to Down syndrome however the history here is inconsistent with glaucoma.

A squint is a deviation in the gaze of an eye.
question: You perform a routine newborn examination on a baby with newly diagnosed Down syndrome. The mother notes 'white speckles on his eyes'. Eye examination is unremarkable with a bilateral red reflex. What is she describing?
question_notes:
Brushfield spots are small grey or brown spots seen on the periphery of the iris. They are associated with Down syndrome.

Cataracts are a clouding of the lens. Although associated with Down syndrome this patient has a normal red reflex therefore a congenital cataract is unlikely.

Coloboma is a congenital defect causing a gap in the lens, iris or retina. It is associated with Patau syndrome, not Down syndrome.

Congenital glaucoma is elevated pressure within the eye. Again there have been links to Down syndrome however the history here is inconsistent with glaucoma.

A squint is a deviation in the gaze of an eye.
title: Down's syndrome: features
body:
Clinical features
  • face: upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthic folds, Brushfield spots in iris, protruding tongue, small low-set ears, round/flat face
  • flat occiput
  • single palmar crease, pronounced 'sandal gap' between big and first toe
  • hypotonia
  • congenital heart defects (40-50%, see below)
  • duodenal atresia
  • Hirschsprung's disease

Cardiac complications
  • multiple cardiac problems may be present
  • endocardial cushion defect (most common, 40%, also known as atrioventricular septal canal defects)
    • results from failure of endocardial cushion fusion, leading to defects in both the atrial and ventricular septa and a single common atrioventricular valve.
  • ventricular septal defect (c. 30%)
  • secundum atrial septal defect (c. 10%)
  • tetralogy of Fallot (c. 5%)
  • isolated patent ductus arteriosus (c. 5%)

Later complications
  • subfertility: males are almost always infertile due to impaired spermatogenesis. Females are usually subfertile, and have an increased incidence of problems with pregnancy and labour
  • learning difficulties
  • short stature
  • repeated respiratory infections (+hearing impairment from glue ear)
  • acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
  • hypothyroidism
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • atlantoaxial instability
concept: Brushfield spots are small grey or brown spots seen on the periphery of the iris. They are associated with Down syndrome.
media:
Trisomy (21, 18, and 13) & Nondisjunction Genetics
Dirty Medicine - YouTube00
 
Down syndrome
Osmosis - YouTube41

2510.concept_text: Down syndrome is associated with hypothyroidism

3056.concept_text: Atrioventricular septal defects are the most common congenital cardiac abnormality in Down's syndrome

3072.concept_text: Brushfield spots are small grey or brown spots seen on the periphery of the iris. They are associated with Down syndrome.

3554.concept_text: Hirschprung's disease is associated with Down syndrome

5345.concept_text: Screen for atlanto-axial instability in people with Down syndrome who participate in sports that may carry an increased risk of neck dislocation (e.g. trampolining, gymnastics, boxing, diving, rugby and horse riding)

6179.concept_text: Down syndrome - pronounced 'sandal gap' between big and first toe

6184.concept_text: Down syndrome - secundum atrial septal defect

6186.concept_text: Down syndrome - isolated patent ductus arteriosus

6190.concept_text: Children with Down syndrome have an increased risk of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

questions:
A 34-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of severe, sharp pain during defecation. She has also noticed bright red blood on the toilet paper. Examination is limited by pain but reveals posterior anal tenderness.

Select the single most likely diagnosis from the options below.
notes:
Anal fissure is the correct diagnosis. The classic presentation of an anal fissure is severe, sharp, or 'tearing' pain during and after defecation, associated with a small amount of bright red rectal bleeding, typically seen on the toilet paper. The pain is often disproportionate to the size of the lesion and can be so severe that patients develop a fear of defecation, leading to constipation, which in turn worsens the fissure. In this scenario, the patient's age, the nature of the pain (severe and sharp on defecation), the type of bleeding (bright red on paper), and the finding of posterior anal tenderness all strongly point towards this diagnosis. Around 90% of anal fissures occur on the posterior midline due to relatively poor blood supply in this area, making it more susceptible to tearing.

Thrombosed haemorrhoid is a plausible differential as it causes significant perianal pain and can be associated with rectal bleeding. However, the pain from a thrombosed haemorrhoid is typically constant and throbbing, rather than being primarily associated with the act of defecation. On examination, a tender, purplish, and firm lump would usually be visible or palpable at the anal verge, which is not described in this patient's presentation. While internal haemorrhoids can bleed, they are typically painless unless they prolapse and thrombose.

Proctitis refers to inflammation of the rectal lining. While it can cause rectal bleeding and discomfort, the pain is not typically the severe, sharp, tearing pain described by this patient, which is so characteristic of a fissure. Proctitis is more commonly associated with symptoms of tenesmus (a feeling of incomplete evacuation), rectal discharge (mucus or pus), and a more constant, dull ache rather than sharp pain specifically on defecation.

Perianal abscess is an infection resulting in a collection of pus near the anus. This presents with severe, constant, and throbbing perianal pain that is not exclusively linked to defecation. Patients are often systemically unwell with fever and malaise. Examination would typically reveal a fluctuant, erythematous, and exquisitely tender swelling in the perianal region, which is a different clinical picture from the one presented.

Colorectal carcinoma is an important differential for any patient presenting with rectal bleeding. However, it is a much less likely diagnosis in this case. Bleeding from a colorectal tumour is often mixed with the stool and can be darker in colour, although bright red bleeding can occur with rectal tumours. Crucially, colorectal cancer is typically painless in its early stages. The presence of severe pain on defecation makes an anal fissure far more probable, especially in a 34-year-old.
question:
A 34-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of severe, sharp pain during defecation. She has also noticed bright red blood on the toilet paper. Examination is limited by pain but reveals posterior anal tenderness.

Select the single most likely diagnosis from the options below.
question_notes:
Anal fissure is the correct diagnosis. The classic presentation of an anal fissure is severe, sharp, or 'tearing' pain during and after defecation, associated with a small amount of bright red rectal bleeding, typically seen on the toilet paper. The pain is often disproportionate to the size of the lesion and can be so severe that patients develop a fear of defecation, leading to constipation, which in turn worsens the fissure. In this scenario, the patient's age, the nature of the pain (severe and sharp on defecation), the type of bleeding (bright red on paper), and the finding of posterior anal tenderness all strongly point towards this diagnosis. Around 90% of anal fissures occur on the posterior midline due to relatively poor blood supply in this area, making it more susceptible to tearing.

Thrombosed haemorrhoid is a plausible differential as it causes significant perianal pain and can be associated with rectal bleeding. However, the pain from a thrombosed haemorrhoid is typically constant and throbbing, rather than being primarily associated with the act of defecation. On examination, a tender, purplish, and firm lump would usually be visible or palpable at the anal verge, which is not described in this patient's presentation. While internal haemorrhoids can bleed, they are typically painless unless they prolapse and thrombose.

Proctitis refers to inflammation of the rectal lining. While it can cause rectal bleeding and discomfort, the pain is not typically the severe, sharp, tearing pain described by this patient, which is so characteristic of a fissure. Proctitis is more commonly associated with symptoms of tenesmus (a feeling of incomplete evacuation), rectal discharge (mucus or pus), and a more constant, dull ache rather than sharp pain specifically on defecation.

Patients are often systemically unwell with fever and malaise. Examination would typically reveal a fluctuant, erythematous, and exquisitely tender swelling in the perianal region, which is a different clinical picture from the one presented.

Colorectal carcinoma is an important differential for any patient presenting with rectal bleeding. However, it is a much less likely diagnosis in this case. Bleeding from a colorectal tumour is often mixed with the stool and can be darker in colour, although bright red bleeding can occur with rectal tumours. Crucially, colorectal cancer is typically painless in its early stages. The presence of severe pain on defecation makes an anal fissure far more probable, especially in a 34-year-old.
title: Anal fissure
body:
Anal fissures are longitudinal or elliptical tears of the squamous lining of the distal anal canal. If present for less than 6 weeks they are defined as acute, and chronic if present for more than 6 weeks.

Risk factors
  • constipation
  • inflammatory bowel disease
  • sexually transmitted infections e.g. HIV, syphilis, herpes

Features
  • painful, bright red, rectal bleeding
  • around 90% of anal fissures occur on the posterior midline.
    • if the fissures are found in alternative locations then other underlying causes should be considered e.g. Crohn's disease

Management

Management of an acute anal fissure (< 1 week)
  • soften stool
    • dietary advice: high-fibre diet with high fluid intake
    • bulk-forming laxatives are first-line - if not tolerated then lactulose should be tried
  • lubricants such as petroleum jelly may be tried before defecation
  • topical anaesthetics
  • analgesia

Management of a chronic anal fissure
  • the above techniques should be continued
  • topical glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) is first-line treatment for a chronic anal fissure
  • if topical GTN is not effective after 8 weeks then secondary care referral should be considered for surgery (sphincterotomy)
    • lateral internal sphincterotomy is the gold standard for chronic anal fissure not responding to medical therapy
    • if sphincterotomy fails or is contraindicated then botulinum toxin injection is sometimes used
concept: An anal fissure usual presents as painful, bright red rectal bleeding

347.concept_text: Chronic anal fissure - topical glyceryl trinitrate

1677.concept_text: An anal fissure usual presents as painful, bright red rectal bleeding

10488.concept_text: Anal fissures - sphincterotomy may be considered for cases that do not respond to conservative management

11257.concept_text: Acute anal fissure (< 1 week): soften stool, dietary fibre, analgesia and topical anaesthetic cream if necessary

options: Extend the forearm at the elbow
Abduct the arm at the shoulder
questions: A 34-year-old contractor has fallen off some scaffolding at work onto his right arm and you suspect a mid-shaft humeral fracture. Which of the following would test the nerve most at risk in this situation?
notes:
Mid-shaft humeral fractures are associated with radial nerve injury. As such, the radial nerve needs to be tested. This may be achieved in a number of ways, but extending the wrist is the only one of the above options that will test radial nerve function (as the radial nerve supplies innervation to the extensor muscles). Palsy of the radial nerve is associated with 'wrist drop'.

Extending the elbow would test the radial nerve, but as the injury is at the shaft of the humerus, innervation of the triceps may arise proximal to a radial nerve injury. This would mean that a more distal injury could be missed. As such, while this will probably be performed, it is not going to give as much information as extension of the wrist.

References:
Shao YC, Harwood P, Grotz MR, et al. (2005). Radial nerve palsy associated with fractures of the shaft of the humerus: a systematic review. J Bone Joint Surg Br; 87(12):1647-52.
question: A 34-year-old contractor has fallen off some scaffolding at work onto his right arm and you suspect a mid-shaft humeral fracture. Which of the following would test the nerve most at risk in this situation?
question_notes:

This may be achieved in a number of ways, but extending the wrist is the only one of the above options that will test radial nerve function (as the radial nerve supplies innervation to the extensor muscles). Palsy of the radial nerve is associated with 'wrist drop'.

Extending the elbow would test the radial nerve, but as the injury is at the shaft of the humerus, innervation of the triceps may arise proximal to a radial nerve injury. This would mean that a more distal injury could be missed. As such, while this will probably be performed, it is not going to give as much information as extension of the wrist.

References:
Shao YC, Harwood P, Grotz MR, et al. (2005). Radial nerve palsy associated with fractures of the shaft of the humerus: a systematic review. J Bone Joint Surg Br; 87(12):1647-52.
title: Radial nerve
body:
Continuation of posterior cord of the brachial plexus (root values C5 to T1)

Path
  • In the axilla: lies posterior to the axillary artery on subscapularis, latissimus dorsi and teres major.
  • Enters the arm between the brachial artery and the long head of triceps (medial to humerus).
  • Spirals around the posterior surface of the humerus in the groove for the radial nerve.
  • At the distal third of the lateral border of the humerus it then pierces the intermuscular septum and descends in front of the lateral epicondyle.
  • At the lateral epicondyle it lies deeply between brachialis and brachioradialis where it then divides into a superficial and deep terminal branch.
  • Deep branch crosses the supinator to become the posterior interosseous nerve.

Image sourced from Wikipedia
In the image above the relationships of the radial nerve can be appreciated

Regions innervated

Motor (main nerve)
  • Triceps
  • Anconeus
  • Brachioradialis
  • Extensor carpi radialis
Motor (posterior interosseous branch)
  • Supinator
  • Extensor carpi ulnaris
  • Extensor digitorum
  • Extensor indicis
  • Extensor digiti minimi
  • Extensor pollicis longus and brevis
  • Abductor pollicis longus
SensoryThe area of skin supplying the proximal phalanges on the dorsal aspect of the hand is supplied by the radial nerve (this does not apply to the little finger and part of the ring finger)

Muscular innervation and effect of denervation
Anatomical locationMuscle affectedEffect of paralysis
ShoulderLong head of tricepsMinor effects on shoulder stability in abduction
ArmTricepsLoss of elbow extension
ForearmSupinator
Brachioradialis
Extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis		Weakening of supination of prone hand and elbow flexion in mid prone position

Patterns of damage
  • wrist drop
  • sensory loss to small area between the dorsal aspect of the 1st and 2nd metacarpals

Axillary damage
  • as above
  • paralysis of triceps

Image sourced from Wikipedia
The cutaneous sensation of the upper limb- illustrating the contribution of the radial nerve
media:
Radial Nerve - 3D Anatomy Tutorial
Anatomy Zone - YouTube150

8226.concept_text: Wrist drop is clinical sign that may be found with a mid shaft humeral fracture

questions:
A 25-year-old female student presents to the GP surgery because her last menstrual period was 5 months ago. Previously she has been having regular periods since she was 13 years old. A urinary pregnancy test is negative. You ordered some blood tests and results are as below:

FSH3.9 IU/L (4.5 - 22.5)
LH0.4 IU/L (0.5 - 50.0)
Oestradiol107 pmol/L (100 - 1000)
Testosterone1.0 nmol/L (0.8-3.1)
Prolactin275 IU/mL (60-600)
T412 pmol/l (9-18)

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Low-level gonadotrophins indicate a hypothalamic cause.

Premature ovarian failure would have high gonadotrophins.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome would have high LH and androgens.

Her prolactin level is within the normal range.

Her thyroxine level is within the normal range.

Testosterone1.0 nmol/L (0.8-3.1)
Prolactin275 IU/mL (60-600)

What is the most likely diagnosis?

Low-level gonadotrophins indicate a hypothalamic cause.

Her prolactin level is within the normal range.

Her thyroxine level is within the normal range.
title: Amenorrhoea
body:
Amenorrhoea may be divided into:
  • primary: defined as the failure to establish menstruation by 15 years of age in girls with normal secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development), or by 13 years of age in girls with no secondary sexual characteristics
  • secondary: cessation of menstruation for 3-6 months in women with previously normal and regular menses, or 6-12 months in women with previous oligomenorrhoea


Causes

Primary amenorrhoeaSecondary amenorrhoea (after excluding pregnancy)
  • gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome) - the most common causes
  • testicular feminisation
  • congenital malformations of the genital tract
  • functional hypothalamic amenorrhoea (e.g. secondary to anorexia)
  • congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • imperforate hymen
  • hypothalamic amenorrhoea (e.g. secondary stress, excessive exercise)
  • polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • hyperprolactinaemia
  • premature ovarian failure
  • thyrotoxicosis*
  • Sheehan's syndrome
  • Asherman's syndrome (intrauterine adhesions)

    • Investigation and management

    Initial investigations
    • exclude pregnancy with urinary or serum bHCG
    • full blood count, urea & electrolytes, coeliac screen, thyroid function tests
    • gonadotrophins
      • low levels indicate a hypothalamic cause where as raised levels suggest an ovarian problem (e.g. Premature ovarian failure)
      • raised if gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome)
    • prolactin
    • androgen levels
      • raised levels may be seen in PCOS
    • oestradiol

    Management
    • primary amenorrhoea:
      • investigate and treat any underlying cause
      • with primary ovarian insufficiency due to gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome) are likely to benefit from hormone replacement therapy (e.g. to prevent osteoporosis etC)
    • secondary amenorrhoea
      • exclude pregnancy, lactation, and menopause (in women 40 years of age or older)
      • treat the underlying cause

    *hypothyroidism may also cause amenorrhoea
concept: Secondary amenorrhoea: low-level gonadotrophins indicate a hypothalamic causes
media:
Amenorrhoea
Osmosis - YouTube103

3307.concept_text: Secondary amenorrhoea: low-level gonadotrophins indicate a hypothalamic causes

11380.concept_text: Raised FSH/LH in primary amenorrhoea - consider gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome)

questions:
A 6-year-old boy is taken to the emergency department by his mother with several days of wheezing. He also describes some chest tightness and is coughing up clear phlegm. He has a past medical history of asthma and uses a salbutamol inhaler when needed. Over the past few days, he has been using the inhaler several times daily.

On examination, a widespread wheeze is noted on auscultation of the chest. Observations are within normal limits for his age. His peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) is calculated as 70% of his historic best value. He can speak in full sentences.

What is the most appropriate next step?
notes:
Oral prednisolone is the most appropriate answer. This child is experiencing an acute exacerbation of asthma. This attack can be described as moderate - his PEFR is between 50% and 75% of his best, his observations are fine and he has no clinical features of severe or life-threatening asthma. Regardless of severity, BTS guidelines state that all children experiencing an asthma attack should be given steroid therapy. For a child of this age, 30-40mg once daily for 3 days is typically used.

Intravenous co-amoxiclav is incorrect. There are no features of infection in this scenario - as such, antibiotics are not warranted.

Intravenous hydrocortisone is incorrect. If the patient were more unwell, or unable to swallow, the parenteral route would be indicated. However, this child seems reasonably well and can talk in full sentences; the oral route will be adequate.

Oral amoxicillin is incorrect. There are no features in this scenario to suggest infection, so antibiotics are not warranted.

Reassurance and monitoring are insufficient alone. Guidance states that all children experiencing an asthma exacerbation, regardless of severity, should be given steroid therapy.

title: Asthma in children: management of acute attacks
body:
Children with severe or life threatening asthma should be transferred immediately to hospital.

Children between 2 and 5 years of age

Moderate attackSevere attackLife-threatening attack
SpO2 > 92%
No clinical features of severe asthma
SpO2 < 92%
Too breathless to talk or feed
Heart rate > 140/min
Respiratory rate > 40/min
Use of accessory neck muscles
SpO2 <92%
Silent chest
Poor respiratory effort
Agitation
Altered consciousness
Cyanosis

Children greater than 5 years of age

Attempt to measure PEF in all children aged > 5 years.

Moderate attackSevere attackLife-threatening attack
SpO2 > 92%
PEF > 50% best or predicted
No clinical features of
severe asthma
SpO2 < 92%
PEF 33-50% best or predicted
Can't complete sentences in one breath or too breathless to talk or feed
Heart rate > 125/min
Respiratory rate > 30/min
Use of accessory neck muscles
SpO2 < 92%
PEF < 33% best or predicted
Silent chest
Poor respiratory effort
Altered consciousness
Cyanosis

For children with mild to moderate acute asthma:

Bronchodilator therapy
  • give a beta-2 agonist via a spacer (for a child < 3 years use a close-fitting mask)
  • give 1 puff every 30-60 seconds up to a maximum of 10 puffs
  • if symptoms are not controlled repeat beta-2 agonist and refer to hospital

Steroid therapy
  • should be given to all children with an asthma exacerbation
  • treatment should be given for 3-5 days

Usual prednisolone dose

AgeDose as per BTSDose as per cBNF
2 - 5 years20 mg od1-2 mg/kg od (max 40mg)
> 5 years30 - 40 mg od1-2 mg/kg od (max 40mg)
concept: Steroid therapy should be given to all children who have an asthma attack
links:
British Thoracic Society1618
2019 Asthma guidelines

11718.concept_text: Steroid therapy should be given to all children who have an asthma attack
